subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: QS news update
msgSnippet: ... I think that is just it, as I am coming to see. English has a greater variety of accents than Spanish. So we either have to have a rigid spelling system or
messageBody:
Anthony Grahn wrote:


>
> I know the goal might be to produce something like Spanish with it's
> universal spelling, phonemic letters and huge variety of accents. But
> this can not be done with English in its current state. The various
> accents have evolved in an incompatible manner over the centuries
> because the language was insufficiently phonetic to begin with.
>

I think that is just it, as I am coming to see. English has a greater
variety of accents than Spanish. So we either have to have a rigid
spelling system or allow variations in spelling.

(Though as a quibble, I don't think you mean that English is not
"phonetic," but that its alphabet never was? But the original alphabet
doesn't really weigh in our problem. Our problem is that English is
spoken so much more variation than Spanish, so that even if we had
absolutely dictatorial power to impose an alphabet on English speakers,
we couldn't create something both uniform and natural.)

What is better, though, to have 3 dictionaries, 3 versions of the news,
or to have one version that is artificially based and does not represent
one's accent? I mean this as an open-ended question.

Paul
